The War Cabinet were informed that a communicationSfar- had been received from the Canadian Government, dated the(Previous 2nd December, to the effect that Canada felt compelled to takeReference: independent action with a view to bringing about the unshacklingW.M. (42) 162nd of prisoners of war, and were considering alternative courses to conclusions,' this end.Mmu.te 6.) jn diSCUSsion, the Prime Minister said that the action proposedby the Canadian Government was very unlikely to result in theGerman Government unshackling British prisoners. The GermanGovernment were seeking a confession on our part that certainactions had been wrongfully taken by our troops in the field of battleand that we would desist from such actions in future.There was general agreement that, if the Canadian Govern-ment were to take action independently of this country, the results would be most unfortunate. It was essential that we should act instep. It was felt that, in the circumstances, the best course wouldbe that we should tell the Protecting Power that, if they wouldappeal to both parties to unshackle their prisoners from a givenhour and day, we for our part would do so.The Foreign Secretary* read to the War Cabinet a draft letter. to our Minister at Berne to give effect to this suggestion. Variousamendments were proposed.The War Cabinefs decisions were as follows(1) The Foreign Secretary would submit to the Prime minister that afternoon a draft telegram to our Minister at Berne(on the lines of the draft read to the Meeting, asamended in discussion) instructing him to tell the swiss government that if they would appeal publicly to our-selves and the Germans to unshackle their prisoners from a given hour and day, we would act on thissuggestion. .(2) Our Minister at Berne should also be instructed to ask the swiss Government to make this appeal in the nearfuture, and to. ascertain the date for unshackling to be proposed by the Swiss Government in their communica-tions tp ourselves and to the German Government.1. W. 1,December 3, 1942.(3) The Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs was invited to telegraph urgently to the Canadian Government tellingthem of the action -proposed under (1) and (2), andsaying that we assumed that they would desist fromaction on the lines proposed in the communication of the2nd December, summarised in the opening paragraphof this Minute.(4) A public announcement on the matter (including publicity for the terms of the reply of the German Governmentto the Protecting Power) must await the Swiss Govern-ment's appeal to ourselves and to the Germans. It was hoped, however, that an announcement on the matter could be made in a few days' time.[These conclusions over-ride W.M. (42) 162ndConclusions, Minute 6, conclusions (1) and (2).]
